background: A banana company sells bananas in small and large crates with different capacities. There's a preference for large crates, but also a requirement for a minimum number of small crates.
constraints: Number of small crates is an integer
Number of large crates is an integer
Number of small crates is non-negative
Number of large crates is non-negative
Number of large crates must be at least MinLargeToSmallRatio times the number of small crates
At least MinSmallCrates small crates should be used
Total number of bananas in small crates and large crates can't exceed TotalBananas
A small crate can hold BananasPerSmallCrate bananas
A large crate can hold BananasPerLargeCrate bananas
objective: Maximize the total number of crates produced
description: A banana company sells their bananas in small and large crates. A small crate can hold \param{BananasPerSmallCrate} bananas while a large crate can hold \param{BananasPerLargeCrate} bananas. Since large crates are more manageable, the number of large crates must be at least \param{MinLargeToSmallRatio} times the number of small crates. However, at least \param{MinSmallCrates} small crates should be used. If the company has available \param{TotalBananas} bananas, how many of each crate should the company use to maximize the total number of crates produced?

parameters.definition: Number of bananas a small crate can hold
Number of bananas a large crate can hold
Minimum ratio of large crates to small crates
